texts.shortText:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This species has a large, blunt head with a steep profile, wide mouth and large, dark, bulging eyes. Above each eye is a bony ridge and a tentacle consisting of a flat stalk, tipped by numerous filaments. The low, even dorsal fin has 31–36 spines and 4–6 rays and neither a raised crest nor notch behind the first few spines.

Body colour mottled cream and brown with indistinct vertical dark bars, a characteristic large brown spot on the operculum and two oblique brown bars below the eye. Pectoral fins large and transparent.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Olifants River on west coast to Eastern Cape.
Common in intertidal rock pools, especially under boulders, less common subtidally. Often the most abundant fish species found in intertidal pools east of Cape Point. Particularly active at night.
Feeds on a wide range of invertebrates. Isopods and amphipods are the most important components of the diet, followed by decapod crustaceans, polychaete worms and barnacle cirri.

All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.

In this species females reach sexual maturity between about 65–80 mm and males at a smaller size of 60–65 mm. The average number of embryos per female is 15 (one of lowest number among species examined) and the size at birth is about 15 mm.
Fairly easily recognised by the blunt head, large eyes and characteristic large, round, black spot on the operculum.

Bennett, B, Griffiths, CL & Penrith, ML (1983). The diets of littoral fish from the Cape Peninsula. African Zoology, 18(4), 343-352.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 328).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 392).

Prochazka, K (1994). The reproductive biology of intertidal klipfish (Perciformes: Clinidae) in South Africa. African Zoology, 29(4), 244-251.

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 763).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 60).
